meta.content: This paper introduces a novel method to reduce the voltage stress experienced by 320 V/1 kW/13.56 MHz electrical variable capacitor (EVC) circuits with an asymmetrical switch configuration applied in the impedance matching circuits of RF plasma systems. The proposed method employs a symmetrical switch configuration in place of the asymmetrical switch configuration in each of the capacitor legs in an EVC circuit. The symmetrical switch configuration reduces the voltage stress in the EVC circuit due to symmetrical charging and discharging modes. As a result, the proposed circuit can be used in etching systems. The major idea is verified by simulation and experimental results, which successfully demonstrate that the voltage stress on the switch of an EVC circuit is reduced by more than 35%.

meta.content: Electrical variable capacitor using symmetrical switch configuration for reducing switch voltage in RF plasma systems - Journal of Power Electronics

This paper introduces a novel method to reduce the voltage stress experienced by 320 V/1 kW/13.56 MHz electrical variable capacitor (EVC) circuits with an asymmetrical switch configuration applied in the impedance matching circuits of RF plasma systems. The proposed method employs a symmetrical switch configuration in place of the asymmetrical switch configuration in each of the capacitor legs in an EVC circuit. The symmetrical switch configuration reduces the voltage stress in the EVC circuit due to symmetrical charging and discharging modes. As a result, the proposed circuit can be used in etching systems. The major idea is verified by simulation and experimental results, which successfully demonstrate that the voltage stress on the switch of an EVC circuit is reduced by more than 35%.

div.p: Advertisement

div.div: Electrical variable capacitor using symmetrical switch configuration for reducing switch voltage in RF plasma systems

header.h1: Electrical variable capacitor using symmetrical switch configuration for reducing switch voltage in RF plasma systems
header.p:
Journal of Power Electronics
volume
20
,
pages
1562–1572 (
2020
)
Cite this article

li.p:
128
Accesses

1
Citations

div.p: This paper introduces a novel method to reduce the voltage stress experienced by 320 V/1 kW/13.56 MHz electrical variable capacitor (EVC) circuits with an asymmetrical switch configuration applied in the impedance matching circuits of RF plasma systems. The proposed method employs a symmetrical switch configuration in place of the asymmetrical switch configuration in each of the capacitor legs in an EVC circuit. The symmetrical switch configuration reduces the voltage stress in the EVC circuit due to symmetrical charging and discharging modes. As a result, the proposed circuit can be used in etching systems. The major idea is verified by simulation and experimental results, which successfully demonstrate that the voltage stress on the switch of an EVC circuit is reduced by more than 35%.

RF plasma is used in various industrial applications [
1
,
2
,
3
,
4
]. One RF plasma system is the semiconductor device manufacturing process. The semiconductor device manufacturing process uses plasma processing at different stages of the process. Plasma processing involves the energizing of a gas mixture by imparting energy to the gas molecules by introducing RF (radio frequency) energy into the gas mixture. This gas mixture is typically contained in a vacuum chamber, referred to as a plasma chamber, and the RF energy is typically introduced into the plasma chamber through electrodes.

In a typical RF plasma process, the RF generator generates power at the RF (which is broadly understood to be within the range of 3 kHz–300 GHz), and this power is transmitted through RF cables and networks to the plasma chamber, in order to provide an efficient transfer of power from the RF generator to the plasma load, where an intermediary circuit is used to match the fixed impedance of the RF generator with the variable impedance of the plasma load [
5
,
6
,
7
,
8
,
9
].

Impedance matchers are required to achieve efficient power transmission in RF plasma systems. Impedance matchers essentially require variable components. The most common types are variable inductors and variable capacitors. However, variable inductors have a disadvantage since they are large and difficult to control. Therefore, impedance matchers use a vacuum variable capacitors (VVCs) that mechanically changes the capacitance. However, VVC takes a long time to achieve a match. In order to reduce the matching time, EVCs using power electronic technology have been recently researched [
10
,
11
,
12
,
13
,
14
].

Amongst the various kinds of EVCs, EVC circuits using an asymmetrical, i.e. unidirectional, switch configuration with a combination of PIN diodes has been introduced to the impedance matchers of RF plasma systems. This type of EVC is characterized by only one active switch in each leg of a capacitor branch. Thus, the total number of active switches in a complete EVC can be minimal. However, due to an asymmetrical switch configuration, the charging and discharging of the capacitor in each leg is done in asymmetrical manner resulting in a relatively high dc offset voltage across the capacitor. This high dc offset voltage leads to a high voltage stress on the active switch. Therefore, the advantage of the minimal number of switches is undermined by this additional requirement of a high voltage rating. This is a significant drawback, particularly for EVCs of high voltage and high power rating utilized for RF plasma systems, where the use of power semiconductors with a high voltage rating is one of major cost factors.

This paper proposes a novel structure for an EVC employing a symmetrical switch configuration. Owing to the symmetrical switch configuration, the charging and discharging of the capacitor in each leg are done in a symmetrical manner resulting in almost zero dc offset voltage across the capacitor. Therefore, when compared to the conventional asymmetrical switch configuration, the proposed circuit topology has reduced voltage stress on the power semiconductor switch. The reduced voltage rating for the switch results in savings in terms of cost and volume for the entire EVC circuit. In this paper, two types of EVC circuits, i.e. asymmetrical and symmetrical switch configurations, are explained through circuit analyses and verified by experiments.

This paper is organized as follows. The theory of impedance matching, including the equivalent circuit, is reviewed in Sect.
2
. Circuit analyses of two types of variable capacitors using modes that depend on the operation of the diodes and switches are presented in Sect.
3
. Simulation and experiment results are illustrated in Sect.
4
. Some conclusions are given in Sect.
5
.

section.data-title: Variable capacitor and impedance matching system in RF plasma systems

div.h2: Variable capacitor and impedance matching system in RF plasma systems

div.p:
Figure
1
shows the configuration of an RF plasma system. The RF plasma system consists of three parts. The three parts are divided into a power supply, an impedance matcher, and a load. An equivalent circuit of an RF plasma system including the proposed circuit structure is shown in Fig.
2
. In EVC circuits, various impedance combinations can be generated depending on the operation of the switch [
15
,
16
,
17
,
18
]. The impedances of the source and the load are matched using various impedance combinations.
Configuration of an RF plasma system
RF plasma circuit with the proposed electrical variable capacitor

The reason for impedance matching is to deliver the maximum amount of power to the load. If impedance matching is not achieved, the output of the RF source does not reach the load. In other words, it is caused by an increase in the reflected power and the plasma state is not maintained. Therefore, problems such as a decrease in the production of semiconductor manufacturing processes and the occurrence of defective products occur. Consequently, a problem arises in the semiconductor manufacturing process.
Equivalent circuit for an explanation of impedance matching theory

However, if the impedance of the load changes, a matching circuit is needed to deliver the maximum power. Figure
4
illustrates an equivalent circuit including the matching circuit. When the impedance (
Z
L
) of the load changes, the impedance (
Z
m
) of the matching circuit also changes. Therefore, the impedance of the matcher is changed to match the equivalent impedance (
Z
eq
) when viewed from the source side with the impedance of the source. The equation for impedance matching can be represented as (
9
). If the impedance of the source consists of a pure resistive component, it makes the equivalent impedance (
Z
eq
) a pure resistive element when seen from the source side.
Circuit for an explanation of an impedance matcher with a changeable impedance circuit

RF plasma systems can be analyzed based on impedance matching theory. Most RF sources have a 50 Ω (
R
in
) impedance consisting of purely resistive components. A plasma load is variable since it always changes depending on the amount and type of gas. As can be seen from impedance matching theory, since the source is composed of purely resistive components, the value of the equivalent impedance viewed from the source side must be maintained at 50 Ω. This is the role of the impedance matcher. Matching the impedances of the source and the load maximizes the power applied to the load.

A single leg system with a fixed impedance plasma load is presented in Figs.
5
and
6
to focus on the voltage stress of the single switch (
S
pn
). A conventional EVC circuit causes high voltage stress on the switch. Therefore, this paper proposes a symmetrical EVC circuit to reduce the voltage stress of the switch. An EVC circuit using the conventional asymmetrical switch configuration and an EVC circuit using the proposed symmetrical switch configuration are illustrated in Fig.
7
.
RF plasma equivalent circuit with an EVC using a single leg asymmetrical switch configuration
RF plasma equivalent circuit with an EVC using a single leg symmetrical switch configuration

Two types of EVC circuits:
a
conventional circuit;
b
proposed circuit

section.data-title: Circuit analyses on two types of electrical variable capacitor circuits

div.h2: Circuit analyses on two types of electrical variable capacitor circuits

div.p:
In this section, circuit analyses are performed to describe the voltage stress on the switch. Figures
8
,
9
,
10
,
11
show equivalent circuits of two types EVC according to the switches and diodes operations. It is defined that the EVC circuit operates in Mode 1 when the switch is on. An equivalent circuit of Mode 1 for the two types of EVC circuits are shown in Fig.
8
. Each voltage and equivalent capacitance of Mode 1 can be represented by Eqs. (
10
) through (
13
).

Equivalent circuit of switch turn on—Mode 1:
a
conventional circuit;
b
proposed circuit

Equivalent circuit of Dnn off and Dpn on during switch turn off–Mode 2:
a
conventional circuit;
b
proposed circuit

Equivalent circuit of Dnn off and Dpn off during switch turn off—Mode 3:
a
conventional circuit;
b
proposed circuit

Equivalent circuit of Dnn on and Dpn off during switch turn off—Mode 4:
a
conventional circuit;
b
proposed circuit

When a switch is turned off, there are three different operating modes (Modes 2, 3, and 4) generated depending on the on/off state of the diodes (
D
nn
and
D
pn
). An equivalent circuit of Mode 2 is illustrated in Fig.
9
. Mode 2 corresponds to the operating state in which
D
nn
is turned off and
D
pn
is turned on while the switch is turned off. Each of the voltage and equivalent capacitances can be obtained by Eqs. (
14
) through (
22
).

div.span: $$C_{{{\text{eq\_sy\_Mode2}}}} = \frac{{\left( {\frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} }} + C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} } \right)C_{n} }}{{\frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} }} + C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} + C_{n} }}$$

div.p:
An equivalent circuit of Mode 3 is presented in Fig.
10
. Mode 3 is defined as the operating mode in which both
D
nn
and
D
pn
are turned off. Each of the voltage and equivalent capacitances can be represented by Eqs. (
23
) through (
33
).

div.span: $$C_{{{\text{eq\_asy\_Mode3}}}} = \frac{{\left( {\frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }} + C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} } \right)C_{n} }}{{\frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }} + C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} + C_{n} }}$$

$$C_{{{\text{eq\_sy\_Mode3}}}} = \frac{{\left( {\frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} }} + \frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }}} \right)C_{n} }}{{\frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_nn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} }} + \frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }} + C_{n} }}$$

div.p:
An equivalent circuit of mode 4 is described in Fig.
11
. Mode 4 corresponds to the operating state in which
D
nn
is turned on while
D
pn
is turned off. Each of the voltage and equivalent capacitances can be represented by Eqs. (
34
) through (
40
).

div.span: $$C_{{{\text{eq\_sy\_Mode4}}}} = \frac{{\left( {\frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }} + C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} } \right)C_{n} }}{{\frac{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }}{{C_{{{\text{o\_pn}}}} + C_{{{\text{oss\_pn}}}} }} + C_{{{\text{oss\_nn}}}} + C_{n} }}$$

div.p:
In general, the switch of an EVC is subject to high voltage stress during switching off transients. The switching off transient operation of the two types EVC circuits are described in Figs.
12
and
13
. The number in the circle designates the operating modes: Modes 1, 2, 3, and 4. During the switch-on time, the voltage of the source is equal to the voltage of C
n
. In Figs.
12
and
13
, it is assumed that the switch is turned off when the capacitor current (
i
m
) is positive. The opposite assumption, i.e. if the switch is off when the current (
i
m
) is negative, gives the same final result.
Voltage and current in each component for a transient analysis of a conventional EVC circuit
Voltage and current in each component for a transient analysis of the proposed EVC circuit

An EVC can be controlled by a switch. If the switch is turned on, the EVC operates in mode 1. If the switch is turned off, EVC changes from Mode 1 to Mode 2. In operation Mode 2, the three capacitors (
C
n
,
C
o_nn
, and
C
oss_pn
) are charged by the current (
i
m
). When the direction of the current (
i
m
) changes, it changes from Mode 2 to Mode 3. The charged capacitors discharge due to the direction of the current, and the discharge rate depends on the value of the capacitors. When the capacitor of the diode is fully discharged and the voltage reaches 0, it conducts and changes from Mode 3 to Mode 4. In mode 4, the charging of the capacitor is reversed to mode 2. When the direction of the current changes, it changes from Mode 4 back to Mode 3. As a result, in Mode 3, the output capacitance of the diode is discharged so that it becomes Mode 2 and Mode 4. As can be seen in Figs.
14
and
15
, after repeating these modes, the circuit is stabilized in Mode 3 when the voltage of the switch (
S
nn
) reaches a value to completely reverse bias both diodes. Therefore, the total capacitance of a single leg under the condition of the switch off state is not determined by
C
n
but by the output capacitance of the pin diode. This is in the range of a few pF, such as Eq. (
41
).
Voltage and current in each component for a steady-state analysis of a conventional EVC circuit
Voltage and current in each component for a steady-state analysis of the proposed EVC circuit

The major difference between asymmetrical and symmetrical switch configurations lies in Mode 4 during which the switch voltage of
S
nn
is charged to a negative potential. Owing to the negative potential of
S
nn
, the pin diode of
D
nn
can be put in reverse bias with respect to the smaller bias voltage on both switches. As a result, the symmetrical switch configuration provides the symmetrical charging / discharging current path. Thus, both pin diodes can be turned off with reduced voltage stress on both switches, i.e. zero offset voltage of
C
n
.

Based on the circuit analysis above, verification of the EVC circuit is guaranteed through simulation and experimental results. Table
1
shows the values used in the simulation. The values of the parasitic capacitance and resistance of the switches and diodes used in the simulation are listed in their datasheets. Since the RF plasma system is a high voltage, high speed system, a SiC MOSFET and a PiN diode are used. The source has an impedance of 50Ω and the load is described as a series connected load. Each simulation circuit describes a RF plasma system using an EVC circuit.

Simulations are performed from 300 to 500 W. Simulation results at 300 W and 500 W are listed in Figs.
16
,
17
,
18
and
19
. In the 300 W simulation results, the voltage of the switch is reduced from 220.3 V to 133.9 V, which is about 39.2% of the voltage stress. In the 500 W simulation results, the voltage of the switch is reduced from 280.2 V to 170.3 V, which is about 39.3% of the voltage stress.
Simulation result of an EVC circuit using a conventional asymmetrical switch configuration [20 V/div] [1us/div]
Simulation result of an EVC circuit using the proposed symmetrical switch configuration [20 V/div] [1us/div]
Simulation result of an EVC circuit using the proposed symmetrical switch configuration [50 V/div] [1us/div]
Simulation result of an EVC circuit using the proposed symmetrical switch configuration [50 V/div] [1us/div]

As can confirmed from the simulation results, the voltage of V
spn
is reduced about 39%. In other words, through simulation, it was successfully confirmed that the proposed EVC circuit with a symmetrical switch configuration has lower voltage stress than an EVC circuit with an asymmetrical switch configuration.

Experiments are also used to confirm the proposed EVC circuit using two types of configuration. The implementation of an RF plasma system with EVC circuits are shown in Figs.
20
and
21
. The parameters for experiment are presented in Table
2
.
Photograph of the experimental setup for testing the proposed electrical variable capacitor circuit with a SiC MOSFET and a PIN diode
Implemented experimental system of the proposed electrical variable capacitor

Low power tests are performed to verify the operation of the conventional and proposed circuits. Figures
22
and
23
show experimental results of the low power test. In the 20 W experimental results, the voltage of the switch is reduced from 30 to 17 V, which is about 43% of the voltage stress. Low power tests confirmed the operation of the conventional and proposed circuits. Experiments are performed from 300 to 500 W. Experimental results at 300 W and 500 W are listed in Figs.
24
,
25
,
26
,
27
. In the 300 W experimental results, the voltage of the switch is reduced from 220 to 140 V, which is about 36.4% of the voltage stress. In the 500 W experimental results, the voltage of the switch is reduced from 280 to 170 V, which is about 39.3% of the voltage stress.

Voltage of
V
spn
using an asymmetrical switch configuration in experiment results (20 W)

Voltage of
V
spn
using a symmetrical switch configuration in experiment results (20 W)

Voltage of
V
spn
using an asymmetrical switch configuration in experiment results (300 W)

Voltage of
V
spn
using a symmetrical switch configuration in experiment results (300 W)

Voltage of
V
spn
using an asymmetrical switch configuration in experiment results (500 W)

Voltage of
V
spn
using a symmetrical switch configuration in experiment results (500 W)

Table
3
shows the voltage of
V
spn
under different operating conditions using both the asymmetrical switch configuration and the symmetrical switch configuration. As can be seen in Table
3
, in the simulation and the experimental results, the voltage reduction rate of the switch is a little different. The gap between experiment and simulation results is due to the parasitic components of the circuit. Nevertheless, with a symmetrical switch configuration, at least 35% of the voltage stress is reduced according to the simulation and experimental results.

figcaption.b:
Table 3 Voltage of
V
spn
under different operating conditions

div.p: This paper proposed an innovative method to reduce the voltage of the switch in an EVC circuit using power electronics technology. The 13.56 MHz RF plasma systems used in the semiconductor manufacturing process have high voltage and low current characteristics. Therefore, reducing the voltage of the switch is a very important part of the EVC circuit. The proposed EVC circuit is very effective in reducing the voltage stress of the switch. This is demonstrated by simulation and experimental results. Simulations and experiments have shown that the switch voltage is reduced by more than 35%. Therefore, the proposed circuit can be applied to semiconductor manufacturing processes using RF plasma. In addition, it is expected that state-of-the-art EVCs can reduce its volume and cost.
